div.p: 1. V:45. Monday.

Rain all day—which confined us all to the house, and Charles could not go to Boston— I visited the garden, and set out one plant of the Downton Strawberry vine but was obliged to return into the house by the rain— I continued the draft of my Will, and wrote part of a page of biography— Compared with Charles a few pages of my father’s Journals with the Copy. It seems impossible to bring them into exact Chronological order, and the writing is so microscopic that it is equally difficult to decypher it. I received this Evening a Note from M Lord, asking for the Manuscript of Dermot— I copied an extract from Hooker’s Translation of Giraldus Cambrensis for a note explanatory of the name, of Dermot MacMorrogh, and an extract from Giraldus himself as an Epigraphe to the Poem— I have many reflections in letting this work go out of my hands under a multitude of discouragements— Its first and great purpose is Moral—but whether it will be understood is doubtful— Whether read—still more so— Mediocris esse Poeta
Non Di—non Homines—non concessere Columnae
2. V. Tuesday.

I finished the draft of my Will—but have yet the Schedules to annex to it, of encumbrances and of property— There is no maxim in Life, so necessary for the transaction of business as the rule of Caesar “Nil actum reputans dum quid superesset agendum” and none which I must charge myself so frequently with neglecting. Charles went in to Boston, and I sent by him the first Canto of Dermot— It is now gone from my hands— Mr Lemuel Brackett was here, for an answer to the proposals he made me last week, but I was not ready to answer. Mr Williams the Collector of the Taxes was here— I paid him part of my tax on Account— The Ladies went to Boston, and Miss Gorham came out to spend some days with Charles’s wife— I wrote a page of Biography, and made a long and fruitless search after the Stamp Act. After dinner I walked round Mr Daniel Greenleafs field, returning by the way of the wharf— Gathered some seeds of the Tupelo—some of the White Beech, and a few Red Oak Acorns— Charles went to my brother’s widows, in the Evening— I read a few pages of Dr Granville, to the Ladies.
3. V. Wednesday.

Mr Thomas Greenleaf brought me a notification, that at a Meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School-fund at Boston, I was elected a member of the Corporation, in the place of my deceased brother, and my Son Charles Francis Adams was elected Clerk— I accepted the trust— I had wished that my Son Charles should be elected a Supervisor, but the foundation requires that they should when elected be Inhabitants of Quincy, which Charles is not— E. Price Greenleaf came, and visited with me my Nursery and Garden. One half my Nursery is already as full of seedling trees, as it will bear— The other will be full in two years more, if I live, and my plantations of this year fail not more than those of the preceding years have failed.— This afternoon I walked over to Deacon Adams’s to bespeak a load of Wood. He was not at home. I left word with his wife. Visited my middle and Druid Pasture Oaks— Found a few Acorns; but not yet ripe. Came out by the foot of Penn’s Hill and walked home— Stop’d at Mr Brigham’s to enquire the prospects of Quincy Canal— Better than the two last years— Training day for the Militia— Boisterous and noisy— John A Newcomb’s address to me—named from my father.
4. IV:30. Thursday.

Morning before Breakfast occupied upon the Schedule of my property to be annexed to my Will— My affairs are so involved and complicated that I have been nearly two Months engaged in drafting and preparing my Will and am not yet ready for signing and sealing I allow myself ten days more to finish— Visited my Nursery and Garden. Planted the Acorns, Swamp Chesnut Oak and White Oak Acorns which I gathered yesterday—between the four which have come up from the Acorns thence planted last Fall— These have grown much less than those from the Red and Black Oaks in D Greenleaf’s pasture— I transplanted into the Nursery a second Downton Strawberry plant— Wrote a page and a half of Biography— I take an excursion to introduce the first employment of my Father by the Town of Boston in 1765.— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— After dinner I walked down to Mount Wollaston. The Apple trees and Forest Trees are perishing for want of care. I saw Alpheus Spear, who still declines to pay the Parish tax, assessed upon the Mount Wollaston Estate— This is a subject which will require great Prudence and Caution.
5. V:30. Friday

Mr Holmes was here with a Land Warrant. Finished the second draught of a Schedule of Property to be annexed to my will— Visited my Garden and Nursery and planted 3. Pignuts and 3. Horse Plum-Stones in a row under the old Apple tree at the lower end of the Nursery— Mr and Mrs Barrell, from Boston paid us a morning visit, but the ladies were gone to Mr Quincy’s— At 2 O’Clock, P.M. the Sale was made of my brother’s Effects, by Deacon Spear at French’s Tavern— I purchased a couple of fowling pieces and a few other Articles— De grand came out from Boston, and shewed me a Letter that he had received from N. Biddle. President of the U.S. Bank— De Grand wished me to write to Mr Biddle, recommending him for President of the Branch at Boston, if G. Green should decline—which I refused, though he was importunate— Mr Price Greenleaf was here returned from Salem— Brought me some Morello Cherry Stones for Seed. De Grand said P. Greenleaf told him yesterday that I was about publishing a Poem. There was a paragraph announcing it in this Morning’s Patriot and Daily Advertiser. P. Greenleaf said Dr Bigelow told him our unknown tree was the Nettle-tree— We spent the Evening with the Ladies at Daniel Greenleaf’s—a Small family party.
6. IV. Saturday— Boston and Medford

I received this Morning the first proof sheet of the Dedication and Preface to Dermot.— Went to Boston with Charles— Call at Lord’s. Returned to him the proof-sheet corrected, and gave with it the Second Canto of Dermot. He asked me for a Psalm or Hymn to have set to Music, and to publish with a collection of sacred Music— I went to Lieutt. Governor Winthrop’s to enquire of his health, and if he could be seen. He could not receive me—he has been these three weeks confined to his bed, and is yet unable to sit up— At the Office of the Hospital Life Insurance Company, I procured a copy of my Power of Attorney to John Angier, to receive the interest upon the deposit of 2000 dollars there in my name, in trust for his wife— Visit at Dr. G. Parkman’s, and I was going with him to visit Mr Audubon, who has just returned from Maine when I found it was too late— Dr Parkman gave me a Syllabus of the course of Lectures on Phrenology, now delivering in Boston by Dr Spurzheim— Met Parkman with Audubon. A. H. Everett casually met us and jocularly hailed me as a Poet.— I went with Charles to Medford. Took possession of the farm mortgaged to me by my brother. dined at Mr P. C. Brooks’s. John Parker. Jos. Tilden, R. D. Shepherd. Gorham Brooks and E. Everett there. Came home this Evening— Miss Gorham unwell.
7. IV. Sunday.

Completed the Schedule of property to be annexed to my Will but that of Debts, and Incumbrances is yet to be added— And it occurred to me this Morning that directions will be necessary with regard to the Trusts committed to me, which will devolve duties upon my Executors— These it will take sometime to mature— Heard Mr Peter Whitney—Communion day— I thought his morning text was from John 18.37. “Every one that is of the Truth heareth my voice”—but believe I mistook him— He administered the Communion, and gave notice that the Services for the Winter would began at Half past 10. A.M. and a Quarter before two afternoon. Miss Gorham dined at Mr T. Greenleaf’s— Louisa C Smith with us— Mr Whitney’s afternoon Sermon was from Luke 11.1.—“one of his disciples said unto him, Lord teach us to pray as John also taught his disciples”— I made a copy of my Sunday Hymn, and wrote to Mr Lord, enclosing it, with my version of the 19th Psalm for him to dispose of them at his pleasure— Read the 3d. Sermon of the second Volume of Saurin—upon Transient Devotions— It was preached 1. January 1710—a Communion day— He gives a tremendous description of the calamities of the year 1709.
8. V. Monday.

Charles went to Boston, and did not return till Evening. I proceeded before breakfast with the preparatory Schedule of debts and incumbrances upon my property, which I found it necessary to revise. Mr Jones of Boston was here to enquire respecting the birth and baptism of two of his wives, who were born here, a Fessenden, and a Crosby, both of which he found on the Parish books— He wished to find also a Record of the birth and Marriage of their fathers, one of which only he found— Henry Hardwick was here, wishing to purchase some standing brush, on my land, near his house— And repeating the application to purchase a strip of Salt marsh, on the Mount Wollaston place— I was two hours in the Garden and Nursery— Planted in the Garden opposite the Nursery Gate, a row of Morello Cherry Stones, and White Beech seed intermixed— I inscribe the names of the Seeds on Slates and Stones deposited beside the Stakes, and sometimes on the Stakes— Transplanted a third Downton Strawberry plant into a Nursery Plant— One Althaea seed of those I planted in August has come up. After dinner I walked to the Lawyers Common. Find a thrifty growth of young Oaks where the Pine and Cedar were cut off last year and the year before— I gathered a few Druid and Middle pasture White Oak Acorns, but they are not yet quite ripe— Fire in my Library chamber
9. V:45. Tuesday.

It was near Sunrise, a quarter before six when I rose this morning, and my writing was proportionably abridged— In my Nursery I planted 3. Rows of Morello Cherry Stones, Mountain Ash berries, and white Beech seeds intermixed in the lower beds, and transplanted there a fourth Downton Strawberry Plant. Examined with Charles, some Manuscript of my father’s oldest Journals and wrote a page of biography— After dinner I went with Charles to Braintree and took possession of the House and farm, occupied by Caleb Hollis which was mortgaged to me, by my brother, and had the minute of it made upon the Mortgage. I walked home alone after looking with little success for Acorns and Apple Seeds— The trees in Goose pasture which bore so well the year before last, have none now— Mr Beale with his daughter Ann, and Price Greenleaf were here this Evening— Mr Beale and Mr Gourgas are going to Worcester to-morrow, to attend the National Republican Convention, to be held there the day after, for the approaching Presidential and Governor’s Elections.
10. IV:15. Wednesday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dinner— Four new Cases of Cholera in Boston yesterday. I wrote the draught of minutes of Trusts, to be annexed to my will— I walked over the hills to the Lawyers Common, where I found Deacon Spear with Harvey Field, selling at Auction the remainder of the wood standing on that lot. There is a very large growth of Hemlock, which they say is good for nothing for fuel—Pine, Cedar, Spruce, Hemlock, Larch and Fir—called by the Germans Needle wood I discriminate between them yet very imperfectly— There is a young growth of Oaks, Walnuts and Maples, which when the large old trees are removed will thrive— And they have come up thick where the old trees have been cut down the three last years— I was four hours out, and returned just in Season to dine— After dinner I wrote a page of biography— The Ladies spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Charles went, but I kept house— Mrs Angier is at her Mother’s on a visit. I read an Address to the working men, by Seth Luther, which has been sent to me. Very violent and inflammatory.
11. IV:45. Thursday.

I wrote a revised copy of the notice of Trusts to be added to the Schedules of Estate, debts and incumbrances which I propose annexing to my will— There are further Lists which should be made, as directions for my Executors; and yet the Will, it is probable will hardly be signed and Sealed, before changes will take place requiring other dispositions Let me remember to keep an open memorandum, in which the changes may be noted as from time to time they may occur— The making of this Will has been too long delayed— Solomon Thayer brought me a bushel of his Wheat, which my Tenant Carr, will sow upon an Acre of ground on the Hill— Alpheus Spear’s experiment has not succeeded. Thayer continues to be successful with his. Our Irish Cook-maid Ann says it is a kind of weed which grows freely among wheat in Ireland, and that it is called Sturdy— Carr is to sow a bushel to an Acre— I received the second proof half sheet of the Preface to Dermot which I revised and despatched back to Lord. Examined the Copy of old Journals of my father, with Charles—made a short visit to the Nursery and wrote a page of biography
12. IV:45. Friday.

Proceeded in the revision of the Schedules to be annexed to my Will— Short visit after Breakfast to my Nursery and Garden— Planted Mountain Ash Berries—Miscellaneous Acorns, White Beech Seeds, and Wild Cherries— Alpheus Spear was here; paid me his Rent for the Mount Wollaston Farm for the last Quarter, and the Parish tax for the last year but declined payment of the tax for this year. He said he, and three others had taken the advice of Squire Metcalfe, who had advised them not to pay it, and they would stand trial as a joint concern.— Morning visits from Mr and Mrs Cruft and Edward Miller— I proposed to Mr Cruft to witness my Will at his house, to which he consented. Louisa C. Smith, Mrs. Angier; Elizabeth C. Adams and Miss Harrod dined with us. I compared copy with Charles, of my father’s Old Journals; and wrote a page of Biography— In the Evening I received from Mr Lord the first proof half-sheet of the Poem of Dermot, which I corrected. I looked to me excessively dull and flat in print—
Craignez dun vain plaisir les trompeuses amorces.
But alea jacta est.
13. III.45. Saturday.

I finished the draught of the Schedules to be annexed to my Will, and it is now ready to be signed and sealed. I am thankful that the opportunity has been afforded me, of disposing of my worldly affairs with deliberation, and implore the overruling power that no indiscretion or folly of mine, may impair or entangle my Estate any further. But that the debts and incumbrances upon it, may constantly admonish me while there is yet time, to a steady course of exertion to redeem the pledges of my faith—do Justice to all claims upon me, and leave to my children means of comfort and support— Miss Julia Gorham a very amiable and intelligent young woman, who has been with us near a fortnight, as a visitor to her friend, and cousin, Charles’s wife, returned with him, this Morning to Boston. Dr Thayer the Genealogist brought his projected Book of Genealogies of certain families of Braintree, and I had much conversation with him— Subscribed for two copies of his Book— Hour in garden and Nursery— Removed Blackberry and Thimble-berry Vines from the boxes— Afternoon walked to Captain Souther’s— He was gone to Hingham— Call at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Mr and Mrs Angier there—to return this Evening to Medford. Found Charles’s wife there, and walked home with her— Received a Half-Sheet of Dermot, for correction.
14. IV:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr Whitney this morning from Matthew 5.45. “For he maketh his Sun to shine rise, on the evil, and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust”— He thought they would not be treated exactly alike in the future world—but that all would finally be saved— His afternoon was addressed to the younger part of his auditory, from Titus 2.6. Young men likewise exhort to be sober-minded. The text of two Volumes of Sermons of Dr Mayhew— Louisa C. Smith dined with us, and Mr Degrand came out from Boston. Following the afternoon Service, we rambled over the hills, and in my Garden and Nursery till Sunset— Coll. Josiah Quincy spent the Evening here. He is to remove with his family to Boston next Wednesday. I read the fourth Sermon of the Second Volume of Saurin—upon the Divinity of Christ. from Revn. 5.11–14. As in other cases he states the objections too strongly for his answers— His argument is feeble— That of Massillon upon the same Subject struck me as more forcible.
15. IV:45. Monday.

I made the draught of Account N. 7. for the Executors of my father’s Will to be presented to the Probate Court— Deacon Spear came and paid me 115:75. upon the Sales of wood on Lawyers common, and in the swamp and gave me his note, payable 1. May next for the balance 285. Of one lot in the swamp sold for 30 dollars he said about one half was upon the land that was my brother’s— He spoke of the Wood land offered me by Lemuel Brackett to whom I desired him to say that I would give him 500 for the lot of 15. Acres. He said James Brackett had 30. Acres of Woodland that he wished to sell for 20 dollars an Acre— The Deacon is to examine my Borland lot in the 600 Acres, for another Sale. After dinner I called upon Captain Souther and asked him for a particular Statement of the property upon which the Assessment of my taxes was made, which he promised to make out for me. I told him that Alpheus Spear had consulted Mr Metcalfe, with regard to the Parish Tax on Mount Wollaston; and had been advised by him to refuse payment of it which he had done— I said I should therefore not pay it, as I was not disposed to have a Lawsuit with Spear— He said he would consult judge Jackson, about what was to be done. Mr Brackett was here this Evening—he declined taking 500 dollars for his woodlot—and said he would report to Mrs Wood the offer of 105 dollars for each of her 3 Notes and Shares of the Quincy Canal.— Morning visit to Nursery and Garden.
16 IV:15. Tuesday

Finished my Account of Exors. of John Adams N. 7. to be signed by Mr Quincy: and presented to the Judge of Probate at Dedham, on the 6th. of next Month. Mrs Miller and Mrs Quincy junr. called here, but our Ladies were riding out— Coming to the years 1766, and 1767. in my father’s biography, I read over again Hutchinson’s account of those years; and turned also to that of Alden Bradford, which I had not before examined— Reviewed also the Collection of Massachusetts State Papers, published by him— This reading occupied my time so that I had none left for writing before dinner. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Mr John Bailey was here after dinner— He is going next week to Washington; to accompany Mrs Bailey’s Mother and Sister Mrs Judson, who is in a deep consumption— He spoke of my Poem announced for publication; and I read to him the best Stanza’s of Canto 4— Received this Evening, the third proof-half sheet—containing the end of the first and beginning of the Second Canto— Also Goodrich’s Geography, a present from the Author

div.p: 17. IV. Wednesday.

I answered a Letter from Mrs Gerry at New-London; and commenced a Memorandum of Subjects for my attention at the approaching Session of Congress— Received the fourth proof half-sheet of Dermot, which I revised— Sent the two by the Mail to Mr Lord— Almost all the Morning after breakfast was consumed in searches for papers— Found the Documents of the Negotiation of the Treaty with Prussia. These occupations deprived me of the time for writing on the Biography— Deacon Spear came, and told me that none of my Land on Pine hill, had any wood on it, fit for sale. I agreed to go on Saturday, and look with him at the Borland lot in the six hundred Acres. He said he had last year and the year before sold all the woods on the Joy, Field, Savil, and Old Adams lots— Lemuel Brackett offers to take 550 dollars for his lot, but I decline— After dinner I made a short visit to my Garden, and planted a row of seeds and berries— Walk to the 6th. Mile-Stone. Evening spent in a last revisal of the fourth Canto of Dermot— Mr Bailey thought there should be an accompaniment of Notes; but my hopes are not sanguine, that a second Edition will ever be called for— If there should not, the Poem is not worth the trouble of annotations— If there should they may be added hereafter.

div.p: 18. IV:30. Thursday—

I wrote to Gales and Seaton and forwarded to them a packet of documents relating to the Negotiation of the second Treaty with Prussia in 1799— Went to Boston with Kirke— Call at E. Cruft’s engaged to go next Thursday at 11. A.M. to his House, to sign and Seal my will—call at James H. Foster’s— Card at T. H. Perkins’s, and T. D. Ward’s— At Lord’s—met S. Allen of Worcester County there. Gave Lord the fourth Canto of Dermot— He uses my 19th. Psalm and the hymn; for his musical Collection called the Choir— Mason Lowell, is the composer of the music— He said he would call the Tune for my Hymn. Quincy, I attended the Meeting of the Trustees of Edward Hopkins’s donation at the Office of B. R. Nichols. 21. State Street— They have procured a substitution of 8 or 10000 dollars for the fee of the Lands in Hopkinton and Upton. Nichols’s Bill 1500 dollars— Stearns’s also considerable. Committees appointed to audit their accounts and invest the new funds— Call at Judge Hall’s— Left my draught of Will with him. Dined at Dr G. Parkman’s—Audubon, James T. Austin—S. T. Armstrong. R. G. Shaw—Dr. F. Parkman, and young Blake there. Took back my draught of Will from Judge Hall after dinner with his Notes— Returned in the Evening to Quincy— E. Jewett here— Paid two instalments for Episcopal Church.
19. IV. Friday

Almost Sleepless Night— John’s child Louisa is very sick, and after a bad night was confined all this day to the chamber. I wrote Letters to my Son John, to Robert Walsh, and to a person named Cuthbertson, in North Carolina, who has written to me, to make enquiries concerning the reputation of a Quack Doctor, Thomson, commonly called the Steam Doctor— And I sent by the Mail the revised half proof Sheet of Dermot— This was my work for the day— I was two hours in the Garden and Nursery with Kirke— Transplanted two Peach Trees; and several Suckers of Plum trees.— Planted a row of miscellaneous seeds, and removed the seedling trees and thimble-berry vine from the box— The roots of many of them have struck root far deeper than the box— I planted three horse chesnuts at the end of Rows, for the Trees to serve as index Stakes. After dinner I was preparing to go to Mount Wollaston; but Deacon Adams called, and Night soon followed. Settled accounts with him for ten Loads of Oak wood, that he has cut and carted for me the last Autumn and the present— Also for the pasture adjoining his which he hires upon Rent; and for the digging of a ditch through my Land, and his own— My Meditations this Evening were not of the cheerful Class.
20. IV. Saturday

My will is not yet signed and sealed— But I have ceased to devote to it the hours before the rising of the Sun— This morning I wrote a Letter to William Jay; to send, with copies of my Eulogy and oration of 1831. I went and viewed with Deacon Spear and his brother William, the Borland lot in the six hundred Acres, upon which I propose to sell the standing wood— That upon almost all my other lots is already sold— I looked at a Wood lot of 30 Acres belonging to James Baxter, which he offers for Sale; and asked Deacon Spear to say to Lemuel Brackett that I would give him 525 dollars for his lot of 15 Acres on Pine Hill. Mr Brackett came in the Evening and declined taking it— He has advertised the wood for Sale, standing upon it— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— After dinner I called upon Mr. Thomas Greenleaf, and requested him to call a Meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School-fund at my house, at 12 O’Clock, Noon, next Saturday, and invited him to dine with me after the Meeting. He promised to give notice of the Meeting to Mr Beale and Mr Edward Miller— Mr Lemuel Brackett was here in the Evening, and declined taking 525 dollars for the lot on Pine-Hill; I wrote to President Quincy, proposing to meet him next Thursday at Boston and Saturday here
21. IV:15. Sunday.

Dr Gray of Jamaica Plains, preached in the morning from Psalm 111.10. “The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom: a good understanding have all they that do his commandments”—and in the afternoon, from Matthew 5.8. “Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God”— Dr Gray dined with us. I wrote to William L. Stone— J. Q. Adams junr was here after the Evening service— He came from Medford yesterday to consult Dr Woodward, upon a troublesome eruption on his face— Mr Vose, of Lancaster, with Mr Ware of the State of Maine, and two others, were here— Vose says he saw me at Washington, eight or ten years since— Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf and Mr Beale spent the Evening here— Beale has sold Thompson’s Island opposite to Squantum to a Company, who purchase it for an agricultural School— I read the 5th. Sermon of Saurin’s second Volume: upon the Torments of Hell— This writer always sees the difficulties of his Subject; but is not remarkably successful in removing them.
22. V. Monday.

I wrote an addition, in the nature of a Codicil, to my Will, in consequence of the remarks upon my draught, by Judge Hall, upon his perusal of it last Week— It is now ready to be signed and Sealed, and I have intended to take every prudent precaution for the Settlement of my property— Charles went to Boston, and did not return till Evening— He has been for several days quite unwell. Deacon Spear was here, and said he should immediately advertise, for a Sale of standing wood upon my Borland lot— About one half of it— He said he thought Ebenezer Adams was half-crazy; for he had proposed to him to purchase Lemuel Brackett’s Woodlot; to sell the wood upon it, and then the Land to me. A Spec—by which they might each make 50 dollars. I told him he might offer 550 dollars to James Baxter, for his Lot of 30 Acres— I received two proof half-Sheets of Dermot, which carry the Poem more than half through the third Canto—five more half-sheets will finish. I revised these two and despatched them by the Mail to Mr Lord. J. Q. Adams was here this Morning, and again at tea— I wasted so much time in the morning, that I lost the opportunity of visiting my Garden and Nursery— North-East Storm all the afternoon and Evening— I was preparing for a methodical assortment of my papers—a work yet to be performed.
23. IV:30. Tuesday.— Cambridge and Back.

I wrote Letters to N. Biddle, Nathan Adams, and to Mary C. Roberdeau— I received an invitation from the Law School at Cambridge to attend the Dedication of their building, erected by N. Dane, for the Professorships of the Law, this day at 1/2 past two O’Clock P.M.— Deacon Spear was here, from James Baxter, and I authorised him to offer 550 dollars for his Woodlot of 30. Acres— Precisely at Noon I left home and rode to Cambridge; called at President Quincy’s, and left at his house the two Volumes of the Latin and English Giraldus Cambrensis, which I had borrowed from the University Library— The Building for the Law School, just finished, was dedicated by a prayer by Mr Palfrey on the ground floor of the building itself— We thence proceeded to the Chapel, where President Quincy delivered an Address upon the dedication of the building, which took him one hour in the delivery.— It contained a tribute of honour and Gratitude to Nathan Dane the founder of the Professorship; and an exposition of the great advantages, of the connection of a Law School, with the Studies of an University— It was listened to with deep attention, and gave general Satisfaction— I called again at his house, where the whole college, and the invited Strangers were present— Returning home I stop’d and paid a short visit to Genl Dearborn. Began reading the New Testament.
24. IV. Wednesday.

I wrote to P. R. Fendall, and began a Letter to John M. Patton of Milton, Pennsylvania, in answer to a long one from him, detailing a scheme of his for a new universal Standard of Weights and Measures— He takes the length of the Mercury in the Barometer; a Standard which Doctor Thornton once suggested to me. Deacon Spear was here twice, about the woodlot offered to me for Sale by James Baxter— There is some question about the Title. He finally brought me a Deed from Joseph Baxter to his Son James in which the quantity is set down at 28 Acres, more or less— I told him I would examine the Records at Boston to-morrow, and answer further afterwards— I transplanted several peach trees from the Nursery to the Garden— After dinner I walked over the hills to the Druid and Middle pastures, and was soon joined by Deacon Josiah Adams— They have cut down a number of large and beautiful Oak and walnut trees, which we are consuming for our own fuel— I gathered about half a peck of White and Swamp chesnut Oak Acorns; and I asked Deacon Adams to bid off a lot or two of standing Wood for me at Lemuel Brackett’s Sale next week— Charles’s wife went in the afternoon with Mr Beale to Hingham to visit her relation Mrs Brooks— Mr Benjamin Bussey was here, while I was out, and left invitations for us to dine with him next Monday.
25. IV. Thursday— Boston and Back.

I finished my Answer to the Letter of John M. Patton about Weights and Measures. Received two Letters from G. Sullivan, and one from J. Connell. Went into Boston with Charles— Met at his office President Josiah Quincy. Went with him, to the Registry of Deeds, where I found he had on the 27th. of August last, discharged the Mortgage I had given to the Exors. of my Father’s Will on the 21st. of Novr 1829— But he has not found the Mortgage itself— I examined the Records for the Title Deeds of James Baxter’s Wood lot, with partial Success— Met Mr H. G. Otis there, and he invited me to dine with him this day— But I was engaged— I called on Mr James H. Foster and went with him to Mr Edward Cruft’s— They two and Josiah Quincy junr witnessed my Will, which I read to them, and signed, sealed, published and declared in their presence— My mind is now at ease upon that subject— I met at my Son Charles’s Office Mr John Marston, who removed to Boston from Quincy last Winter. He asked me for one of my Bank Reports, upon which he said he should make remarks. He told me he had yesterday met a very warm friend of mine, who told him he heard I was about to publish a Poem, and he heard it was not worthy of me— Degrand told Charles, people were carping at it very much— This before any body has seen it, shews what I am to expect when it comes— I called on Lord and left with him revised the proof half-sheet I had received this Morning. Conversation with him about further projects of publication— Dined with Charles at James H. Foster’s— Mr Frothingham there— Home to Quincy about dusk. The Ladies had come back before dinner.
26. IV. Friday.

Sharp Frost, and a cold clear sky, which caused me to lose much of the early morning; I wrote a short answer to the two Letters received yesterday from George Sullivan, and it occurr’d to me that when my fingers pinched with cold, cannot write, the mind is yet free to compose, and I meditated a Stanza to substitute to the Poem of Dermot for that which in the fourth Canto, will be suppressed. Deacon Spear was here; but The uncleared questions of Title to Baxter’s Wood lot made it necessary to postpone the conclusion for further trial— Charles went to Weston; but missed of seeing the Tenants who were gone to Boston— I planted in the Garden a row of one hundred and a row of fifty Druid White Oak and Swamp Chesnut Oak Acorns, which I had gathered the day before yesterday. And one row in the Nursery near the Elms, mixed with pignuts. After dinner I looked over some of the tattered old Letters of John Norton, father and Son, and of S. Shepard— John Norton’s wife was a Sister of Samuel Shepard— John Kirke and his wife and child, went to Boston this Morning and did not come back at Night.
27. IV:15. Saturday.

John Kirke with his wife and child got home about six this Morning: alive. He overset the Chaise last Night, and they all escaped marvellously not unhurt, but without neck or limb broken— There was a Meeting at Noon of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School Fund— My Son Charles was sworn as Clerk of the Corporation, by the President Thomas Greenleaf and a Committee was appointed to report upon sundry Subjects— The Meeting adjourned before two and the Members of the Corporation, with Mr Whitney and Messrs. Daniel and Price Greenleaf dined with us— Mr Ellis of Dedham came in after dinner and brought me a dozen of apples— He spoke also of his letters to General La Fayette, and of politics new and old— Evening in parlour Conversation with the Ladies— Wrote only a short answer to E. Macdaniel and revised the 11th. proof half-sheet of Dermot, which I received by the mail this morning and despatched again at Noon. Composed a Stanza upon Commanders and Poets—born— Kept house all day.
28. IV:30. Sunday

Frosty Morning. Letter to my Son John— One Stanza Supplementary, for Dermot. Mr N. Bowes Whitney preached this morning from Matthew 14.8. “She hath done what she could”—and in the afternoon from Luke 15.7. “I say unto you, that likewise joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons which need no repentance.” Mr Whitney dined with us, and Mr. Degrand from Boston, who also remained to tea and until 8 this Evening; talking of Politics and electioneering. I read Saurin’s Sermon upon the ravishment of St. Paul from 2. Corinthians 12.2.3.4. a difficult text to deal with treated in an interesting manner— This was doubtless a vision in a trance— Paul himself says he can not tell whether he was in the body or out of the body—but that he heard unutterable words, which it was not lawful to speak— Saurin’s Sermon undertakes to explain why it was not lawful to speak the words, chiefly because the joys of the blessed in Heaven are such as man in his fallen condition is not able to comprehend or to relish— There was Snow and Hail this Morning—and I had no time for occupation, from the Morning Bell till nine in the Evening—
29. V. Monday. Dine at Jamaica Plains. B. Bussey’s—

Day continued wintry cold— Composed a supplementary Stanza, for Dermot. Received the 12th. half proof-sheet, which I revised and returned by the Mail. Charles went to Boston, and returned for dinner— We all went and dined at Mr Benjamin Bussey’s at Jamaica Plains— The Company were General Dearborn and his daughter Julia—General and Mrs Joshua Wingate. Mr and Mrs Abbot Lawrence, Miss Wingate—Mr and Mrs Kuhn, Mrs C. Davis and her daughter Miss Maria Davis—Dr Gray the Minister and Mr Pierpont. Mr Bussey continues to live magnificently.— He told me that he had completed his will, and that I was named in it as one of his Executors— That one copy of it was in the hands of Chief Justice Shaw, one in his own, and a third, I recollect not with whom— That he had after making his Will purchased an addition to his farm, and, conveyed it by a codicil, as a Supplement to his foundation— He told me that for the first Time, his Cloth manufactory at Dedham had not yielded this year one dollar of profit. He said he had upwards of one hundred thousand dollars invested in it— Kuhn told me that unless there should soon be a change they will be obliged to stop— The duty on wool being disproportioned to that on the manufactured Article— Mr Pierpont spoke of my Poem, and predicted bitter criticism— We came home about 8 in the Evening— Charles’s wife lost a bracelet.
30. IV:45. Tuesday.

The cold pinches my fingers in the morning, and I am unable to write— I composed a Stanza for Dermot without deciding where to bring it in— I could enlarge the poem at pleasure, should the public not judge it already too long— Received this morning the 13th. proof half and the quarter sheet or four pages, which close the work—108 pages. I revised, and sent them back by Charles who went in to Boston— He returned to dinner and brought a note asking for some of the copy already printed— I sent it by Mr Foster, who came out this afternoon with his daughter Mary— He asked me for a Letter of Introduction for William who is going to Philadelphia, and I gave him one to Dr John Hopkinson— Mrs H. G. Otis, and her daughter Mrs Ritchie, paid Mrs Adams a visit, but she was riding out and did not see them— Mr Otis was with them— Louisa C. Smith dined and spent the Evening with us— I was part of the morning in the Garden; sowed two rows of Druid White Oak Nuts, Nettle-tree berries cherry-stones and Pignuts—and I transplanted four of the Pear-trees, from Suckers budded last year by E. Price Greenleaf.
31. V. Wednesday.

One miscellaneous Stanza. My thoughts are good and sufficiently poetical, but want pointing— Mrs Adams, and Charles’s wife went to Boston, and returned to dine— I received a Letter from President Quincy enclosing a Subscription paper for the purchase of a new apartment for the Massachusetts Historical Society—an upper Story over a new building for the Savings Bank— I answered the Letter, and subscribed 100 dollars— Visited the Garden— Transplanted Seedling Apple trees, from a large box to my garden nursery— Examined the roots of Peach trees and found them all nearly girdled by the worms— Charles picked out a number, and a shovelfull of ashes was put round the roots of each tree— Mr Brooks and Miss Gorham came out from Boston, but were disappointed, in missing the Ladies, who had not returned from Boston. Louisa Smith also called here— Towards Evening we had a visit from Mr Cazenove of Alexandria, and his Son, a merchant in Boston, who were on their return from Plymouth— The father had a fragment of the Plymouth Rock in his pocket.

Day— Rise between four and five— Read 3 chapters and write or compose till 8— Breakfast—one hour— Read Newspapers or Letters; visit the Garden and Nursery—compare with Charles the copy of my fathers Journals—write diary and trifle away leisure till two—dine—one hour— Walk over the hills, visit the garden and trifle again till dark. Read 3 or 4 Letters of Madame de Sevigne, and pass the remainder of the Evening with the Ladies, in conversation or reading— Much time wasted.
